voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Windward revolves around a simple premise. You are a captain. You have a boat. There is a map. With Pirates, treasures and a whole host of factions, instances and gear! So much gear, so many stats... so little time to sink your teeth into the wheel and get blasting those pesky pirates from the scurvy seas!

Overall, Windward has a great level of polish, with issues addressed frequently by its one man development team... frankly remarkable. The controls are easy enough, and the battles fast paced but not dependent on to much skill/knowledge. You have your conventional holy trinity of damage, defence and healer each with their own skill tree, and stat modifiers. The game does have its limitations, however these are in my humble opinion minor in comparison to the replay-ability.

Instances are fun, with a familar MMO feel, and the community doesn't seem riddled with pesky kids being overtly childish in a bid to ruin your fun. At this stage there seems little end to Windwards potential, except maybe spaceships... I don't see that working!

My advice, if you like Patrician 3/4 or any of the old ascaron games, but felt the battles were a tad arduous. Try Windward. Trade is an option but not the focus of the game, town development has been dummed down also. But then this game is all about the battles and the timing of shots! I've sunk some hours into it already.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I am addicted to this game.  Pretty simple at it's core:

- you have a ship, weapons/equipment, and crew (all upgradeable)
- you can trade, fight, and perform tasks to gain gold and resources
- there is mmo-style online play for control over that server's worldmap (5 factions players can choose from and swap)
- there is instance-based play

You can choose how you want to acquire xp and resources.  Trading and questing is very relaxing.  Contesting a region is very exciting and challenging, especially when other players get involved.  There are reported to be 750 player levels.

Really reminds me of some old classics (Escape Velocity series, maybe Pirates!).  The price is right, too.

reviewText:
To say this is a great game doesn't go far enough.

It is a game that does all the little things right. It's like Sid Myer's Pirates!, but without the dancing, in a completely generated world so it is different each time you play.

You want to quest and trade between cities and be left alone? You can do that.
You want to blow stuff up and never quest or trade? You can also do that.

The combat is fast and fun, but complex enough to be rewarding.

Each of the factions bring a different approach to gameplay, yet you can be successful with any of them.

The game developer is very proactive with his game and, if you play on a public server, you will probably run into him.

Do yourself a favor, and buy this gem of a game. You can't beat the price for such a great game.

reviewText: This game is a mixed bag. On one hand, it is rather enjoyable to sail around and decimate pirates in a glorified colonial-era motif. The combat is simple to grasp and the upgrade tree really forces the player to make choices on equipment rather than paying X gold for a reskinned version of your current arrangement. The rendering is smooth and the battles are frequent enough to keep one interested, which is important because the worlds will bleed together. However, that package comes with a rather grind-heavy level system (even for an RPG, the mechanics scream tedious fetch quests). The singleplayer falls flat, and that remains the biggest disappointment for people who don't want to venture into multi-player maps. I can't say the game is bad, far from it. But I can't recommend it at full price either.\n\nI suppose the best analogy I can think of is the first Assassin's Creed game: beautiful interface, pseudo-historic setting that doesn't worry about the banal details, exciting concept, but the whisps of exploration fun are drowned out by obvious campaign lengthening quests.

reviewText:
its a lot of fun for mindless seek and destroy sea battles. if you have the inclination, the micro-management of the port trading can be interesting too. it takes a LOT of repetitive questing to upgrade the ports of an area of ocean (simulated by a line of squares on the larger world map. loot upgrades are insane to try and manage. like the Diablo loot system it's based on, Windward's loot generator is crazy. each part of a ship's equipment affects a number of the ship's stats, including some that make no sense at all (such as cannons that upgrade ship speed or maneuverability).  in my opinion, the developers need to overhaul the loot and make upgrades that make sense (Hull Plating for defense, Sails for speed and agility, Cannons for damage and range, etc.)

i have to say that the customizability of the maps needs work too. if you try to just increase the size of your world, you end up with adjoining sea tiles that are vastly different in difficulty (6, 9 or more levels to progress to the next tile). guides say to adjust the difficulty for adjoining tiles to  within 3 levels. if your world is gigantic, this takes WAY too long. imagine changing the difficulty on 200 tiles of ocean. there should be a button that makes that 3-level scale automatic, or the game should have tile scales based on the slider difficulty of the game.

fun game, but needs some polishing.

reviewText:
When I look at a game, the first thing I do is check out the actual player reviews. I look for the negative ones first. Not from a bad news perspective but because, I want to know if they think a game is worth the money they paid for it.

So right now, I see Windward selling for $14.99. (Though right now it's on sale, I still look at the base price.)

I and a buddy tend to play games together, and so I look for the features of a game next, as well as if it's something that is in both our wheelhouses.

This game crossed our path after we recently took a break from a different game. (7 Days to Die)

We looked it over, the videos seemed pretty simple, it was going to be about sailing, but not a sail simulator. It was going to be about trading commodities from town to town, but not an economic simulator. It would involve quests that would bring in wealth, where you can deliver goods, pick up goods, ferry passengers, smuggle goods, capture pirate ships, defend towns, build lighthouses and watchtowers, and even build new towns themselves. That seems like it's billed correctly. There is also the exploration aspect of the game, explore new regions, find new towns, encounter pirates and other factions.

That so far, sounds like it's meeting it's advertising. Then it involves getting in and playing, and finding out how quick it is to pick up on the various aspects of the game.

What seems like grinding to those with the attention span of gold fish, can alternatively be seen as growing the region, training your crew and upgrading your equipment. There are RPG elements to the game in the leveling of captains, crew, equipment, ships and more.

Well that's a fun thing to do as we continue to strive to expand our wealth, and beat back Pirate forays into the region.

So with a good number of hours under my belt.

I can say this game is well priced for the entertainment it brings. Fun adventures exploring a map, settling towns and naming them as well.

So it's got a lot of fun positives.

Pros
Easy to learn - Principles of the game are easy to pick up and learn from observation.
Quick to play - You can drop into the game for a few minutes here and there, do some combat, or trade, or both.
Difficult to Master - The average player is used to having their hand held through everything, this game let's you understand the easy aspects, but the nuances of trade and combat and even exploration are at times complex.
Visually Attractive - Looks pretty, and there is minor ship customization cosmetically.
Pricing - Good price point for a fun casual game
Addicting - It's got that one more turn mentality baked into it. You urge to learn and explore.

Cons
Little documentation - You can go to a wiki or even read the beginners guide here on Steam. But not much explained at all. (Some actually like this convention and see it as a plus, that it lets you learn it's secrets.)
Co-Op Play - If you're used to being able to clicking on your friends who are gaming and then joining them in game. This will be an exercise in frustration. You'll need to set up either a server or do some port forwarding, and other hoo haw stuff to get a private server up and running or a direct connection. The best way I've found is go to a public server that is up frequently, and have your friend meet you there. You can then join a private instance if you're inclined or participate in the general map multiplayer play.
Special Combat Options - Others have indicated combat is a case of doing a circle of death, waiting for special buttons to pop up that you can initiate. These often do feel a bit detracting. But again it's a casual game, and millions of people planted crops on other casual games that weren't nearly as interactive as this one.


Verdict: Addicting purchase. Go for it, especially if you see it on sale. Otherwise it's still worth the $14.99 it's selling for. For some this could be a several hundred hour to a thousand hour game, from a shelf-life. (And that's not even including any future updates, or even DLC's or expansions of the game.)

This feels like a more casual spiritual successor to Sid Meier's Pirates! Addicting!""

reviewText:
BEST PIRATE GAME AT THIS TIME....


A very good game to play.  I have been waiting for a successor to Sid Meier's Pirates!" for a long time now and this is pretty darn good.  It got rid of the sword fighting
recommended: and has no treasure seeking option on land
hoursPlayed:
(this is a pity).

The game play in terms of combat is much better than its predecessor in every way.  It is really good fun in my opinion.  This is one of those games in which I find that after having played for about an hour I find out to my amazement that four or five hours have gone by in a flash!

The graphics are very good.  The game can be readily played without any great learning required.  Customization is well implemented.  Sound is fine.  Very playable.  Easy to use interface.  Instances are a great idea and easily made use of.  You can build new towns as well.

I really enjoy the method of infiltrating and taking over zones one by one and then developing them.  It was a great idea that is implimented in this game.  The abilty to then quickly jump from zone to zone without having to sail there the long and boring way is also a fine idea that works well.  I am playing this game with a lot of enjoyment and belive it to be a well built game.  I rate it 9/10.

My only wish is that there could be a few additional side questing aspects to the game to make it even more captivating.  Perhaps some way of spending part of your loot to create or build things other than for your ship.  Perhaps even a special home base/town that can be lovingly created by the player and added to as time goes by as a personal reward for all of your effort.  Perhaps by treasure questing on land they can find the objects with which to build their monument to themselves. Then having conquered the seas the player can admire and relish owning something customized and created by their own hand as a final personal in game reward.  ( I would really like an excuse to park the ship and go onshore from time to time).

I do hope that with lots of support the developer might add a few more interesting aspects to this already fine game and turn it into a real classic that takes away the mantle from its predecessor.

This game is well worth buying in my view."

reviewText:
Windward revolves around a simple premise. You are a captain. You have a boat. There is a map. With Pirates, treasures and a whole host of factions, instances and gear! So much gear, so many stats... so little time to sink your teeth into the wheel and get blasting those pesky pirates from the scurvy seas!

Overall, Windward has a great level of polish, with issues addressed frequently by its one man development team... frankly remarkable. The controls are easy enough, and the battles fast paced but not dependent on to much skill/knowledge. You have your conventional holy trinity of damage, defence and healer each with their own skill tree, and stat modifiers. The game does have its limitations, however these are in my humble opinion minor in comparison to the replay-ability.

Instances are fun, with a familar MMO feel, and the community doesn't seem riddled with pesky kids being overtly childish in a bid to ruin your fun. At this stage there seems little end to Windwards potential, except maybe spaceships... I don't see that working!

My advice, if you like Patrician 3/4 or any of the old ascaron games, but felt the battles were a tad arduous. Try Windward. Trade is an option but not the focus of the game, town development has been dummed down also. But then this game is all about the battles and the timing of shots! I've sunk some hours into it already.

reviewText:
If you liked the sailing in Sid Meyer's Pirates, you'll love this game.  Rather than a large, open world, everything takes place on a series of maps and, if you desire a bit of privacy for yourself and friends, instances.  You can even host and play the game in a LAN party locally, or by direct-connection to a private server.

In gameplay, you choose a faction to start with, are assigned a basic ship, and can quest/trade or hunt down pirates to fill your own personal coffers and increase your experience level, which unlocks more difficult areas and provides talent points that increase your capabilities.  Higher areas = more money and experience.  Towns can be leveled up through a combination of trading and questing, which unlocks access to purchase and then choose between new ships.

If you like a peaceful game that can be played at your leisure, then this game is for you.  If you like teaming up with friends and blowing the competition away, this game is also for you.

Cons: some content is still being worked on, and the end game can be a bit sparse.  Definitely a game to be savored and not rushed through.

reviewText:
I find this to be a very pleasing and enjoyable game and is one I'm still playing on a nearly daily basis. The gameplay is simple, but can still be a challenge. The graphics are vibrant and change based on the different climate of whatever region you visit and with day/night cycles. The music fits the game very well with a cycle of simple, but unobtrusive melodies. The sound effects are just right, from cannon fire to the ship creaking as you change direction to catch the wind.

Windward is a casual trading/city building game where you complete quests such as ferrying passengers to nearby town or hunting down pirate well as buying and selling goods to raise money to buy your next big ship.

It also has exploration and conquest where you have to squash the pirate threat when you enter a new territory. You won't be able to trade or gain quests until the pirates are driven out. You engage in ship to ship combat using you cannons and then as the game progresses other abilities such as throwing barrels of fiery oil, poisonous barrels of rotting fish, the fog of war to mask your position and the old standby of just ramming into your enemy.

When you start, you're a lone buccaneer who must put together other ships in your fleet. The most direct way is to either capture the other pirates or bribe them to join you. Once you have a crew, they will come to your aid when you're attacked as well as engage pirates on their own and work to secure ports. Once a region is secure, you can trade between the cities to build up money and skills or you can move on to the next region and engage more pirates.

As you explore you can dives for treasure amongst the wrecks or pick up flotsam that is washing ashore. This can contain gold, wood, iron, sails, cannons, and even crew members. You then keep building up your attack fleet to engage the enemy. You will also gain XP which can be used to increase the skills of your crew in attack, defense and negotiation.

People say the game is slow and there is a lot of grind. If you prefer endless hordes in an FPS, then yes, this is mild by comparison. If you expect to do something once and move to the next level, then no, it doesn't work that way. You will have to trade goods to make money. You will have to buy bigger boats to trade more goods to make more money. You will need to make money to buy bigger boats so you can defeat the bigger ships the pirates will have. In essence, you will have to trade. The progression makes perfect sense to me and the game has a mixture of both easy, moderate and difficult regions on the same playing grid.

This is a great game at the retail price, but is a downright steal at $5. There has been a nice stream of updates and new features and bonuses have been added, not to mention Steam Workshop integration.  I think this is a great blend of action and adventure and can provide hours of enjoyment.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Pirates was one of my first Sandbox games. I loved almost everything about it, although I was never too keen on the cartoony graphics and the lack of multiplayer.

Windward on the other hand, incorporates practically everything that made Pirates great (minus the treasure hunting and swordplay minigames). If you are looking for a customizable open world Trading, Privateering, and Naval Combat RPG then you have found it in Windward.

The only downside is that the Online presence is rather small, and this is where the game shines. Contesting cities and zones against other players while organizing your AI ships and Trade/Quest Runs is where this game really shines. That being said, a few friends could really have a blast with this game and a private server.

reviewText:
Windward is a bit more straightforward than I anticipated from the description, but it's still fun enough and on a big enough scale that I've gotten dozens of hours of enjoyment from it. Start with a simple ship, by fighting and quests improve your equipment and skills, and help your faction wrest control of the map from the pirates or other factions. Powering up and slowly taking over a map really scratches an itch of mine.

Quests are pretty basic--you're either delivering things to one or more places, or fighting pirate ships. Taking over new squares of the map from pirates are where I found the real fun, but also some frustration--I can totally understand other reviewers who trash the solo game for this. As a solo player, it sometimes feels like you're the only sensible player in a 5v5 game of idiots. You might find yourself trying to single-handedly fight off the pirates being spawned from their single remaining town while your allies are dicking around in safe territory. Or even if you vastly outpower the enemy need to reconquer towns multiple times because the tower-based defenses aren't great and you can't count on allied ships to defend sensibly. It is possible to hire your allies to either stay with you or go to a destination of your choice, but this control is pretty limited.

However, fighting off the pirates is enough fun that I don't really mind the protracted battles--it's one of the best ways to get new equipment and experience, anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm surprised how little attention this game has received and how few reviews it has because, honestly, it's a really fun solid game. And while it's Early Access, it feels very complete.

I bought the game on a whim because it reminded me of Sid Meier's Pirates. And in a way it's similar - it's a pirating game with some questing and trading mechanics, but it really isn't Sid Meier's Pirates either.

The game has very solid combat mechanics and RPG-like elements to it. Ships can be upgraded through switching out different materials (your crew, your cannons, your sails etc) and because they're not permanent, you can switch it out depending on your whims.

Naval combat is somewhat automated - cannons fire automatically within range - but you have custom attacks that you can trigger manually. So far I've only unlocked volley shots and chain shots but the videos show that there are significantly more.

Trading is simpler but still rewarding. If you've explored the towns, they'll tell you which area provides the cargo they would want to buy. There's less planning involved and it feels more like a fetch quest but it's still satisfying to sail across the virtual seas.

There are pirates that roam the seas and other factions as well. You can bribe the pirates and you can capture the cities/towns that the pirates have control of too.

You can level up and unlock skills as well, and I believe your crew and captain rank and level up too - albeit at a different rate. But at any time you'd like you can switch to a different captain or crew (they essentially act as passive items) too.

I'll admit I wasn't entirely convinced of the graphics on the screenshots - they looked a tad jagged and oversaturated and the waters looked dull. But rest be assured, it looks much better animated. It's a beautiful indiegame.

For $14.99, it's a wonderful game.

Pros
- Beautiful graphics
- Solid trading, questing and combat mechanics
- Lightweight game
- Solo or co-op gameplay

Cons
- I hope the trading and questing mechanics is developed upon a little more
- The difficulty from Challenge 3" to "Challenge 4" is akin to the leap from racing a car in Need For Speed Underground to racing a car in Grand Turismo 5
date: there's a sudden difficulty climb that can feel overwhelming."

reviewText:
To say this is a great game doesn't go far enough.

It is a game that does all the little things right. It's like Sid Myer's Pirates!, but without the dancing, in a completely generated world so it is different each time you play.

You want to quest and trade between cities and be left alone? You can do that.
You want to blow stuff up and never quest or trade? You can also do that.

The combat is fast and fun, but complex enough to be rewarding.

Each of the factions bring a different approach to gameplay, yet you can be successful with any of them.

The game developer is very proactive with his game and, if you play on a public server, you will probably run into him.

Do yourself a favor, and buy this gem of a game. You can't beat the price for such a great game.

reviewText:
fun game.

mechanics are fairly simple- sail about, shoot things, capture things, trade and haul freight.

but what actually happens, is that once you have one city your faction will team up to help you, and once you meet all of a towns shortages it will upgrade in size. past a certain point those upgrades need more distant resources, from other zones, so you need to expand your infuence further out.

early on the instances are the best way to level up, and may be an easy way to snag a cargo or scarce or rare cargo quickly. and aside from buying bigger ships, you also need to buy better equipment for those ships.

RTS elements in what is otherwise a ship fighting and trading game. works fine solo, at least on the easier difficulties.

reviewText:
Windward is a very relaxing but sometimes action packed game.  The music and visuals are very relaxing most of the time.

You will ferry passengers from one port to another, get involved in trade, and of course engage in ship to ship battles and then grab the loot from your fallen enemy. The best way to describe it is Diablo/Dungeon Seige on the Sea. Though item stats seem less randomized than those games, which some may see as good, while others may see it as disappointing,

You can buy different ships with different stats and cargo capacity and so on. Each ship can be outfitted with sails, hull material types, cannons, etc all of which you can buy from most port towns, or you can sink some ships and try grabbing loot that way as well.

The game also has random world generation and the ability to choose varying map sizes. You also have several factions that you can allign with.

I have not tried the multiplayer yet, but you can host your own server and enable or disable PvP.

Overall the game is very good. I personally would prefer more of a Diablo approach to loot, but it is fine the way it is currently.

I would give Windward a solid 8/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The controls are simple and there are a few different game types to keep it interesting (so far)  - trading, exploring, questing, fighting.

You gain levels that give you access to more points that you can use on talents and specialisations to customise the play of your avatar (ship) with different abilities in such as defensive ones that provide debuffs and offensive abilities. You can buy different ships or upgrade your existing one (in turn changes the look) with items you purchase or find, you can gain experience through the different game types.

The whole map is broken up into section squares (as viewed from the fast travel map) that have set instances for level ranges of players. Players starting in a game seem to only select areas that are not higher then their level, however can travel into them manually later if they wish.

The end game seems to be a strategy take over of the generated map, adding defensive buildings, capture and holding areas to take them over - I would imagine in later levels require more team work. Not sure I quite understand the rewards for doing so though.

reviewText: Ignoring a few nights of tabbing out, I think I've played Windward for about 20 hours and discovered that the boat combat genre is something I need in my life. Being a big fan of the rogue-like genre, Windward plays like a shallow Diablo/Torchlight/Path of Exile with the restraints around boat combat mechanics. I only say shallow as I wished there was more variety in the in-game activities.\n\nIt is obvious that the developers spent the brunt of their effort on combat, and it shows in how smooth(mostly) it plays out. Fights can be very simple 1v1 focusing on positioning, or they can be chaotic brawls with narrow escapes. There is some variety in ship configurations, with tank and spank" and "hit and run" being the two successful configurations I went with. However

reviewText: Ignoring a few nights of tabbing out, I think I've played Windward for about 20 hours and discovered that the boat combat genre is something I need in my life. Being a big fan of the rogue-like genre, Windward plays like a shallow Diablo/Torchlight/Path of Exile with the restraints around boat combat mechanics. I only say shallow as I wished there was more variety in the in-game activities.\n\nIt is obvious that the developers spent the brunt of their effort on combat, and it shows in how smooth(mostly) it plays out. Fights can be very simple 1v1 focusing on positioning, or they can be chaotic brawls with narrow escapes. There is some variety in ship configurations, with tank and spank" and "hit and run" being the two successful configurations I went with. However

reviewText: The visual presentation of Windward is great, and the combat doesn't require too much of the play but is still very fun. I spent a lot of time being a merchant, buying goods in one port and selling them in another port, or ferrying passengers. And while that's exactly what I wanted from this game, I can see others becoming bored since there are very few quests with any kind of storyline attached. There isn't much in game reason to push into pirate controlled regions other than seeking more gold to buy better ships. You are questing and selling goods to have more gold and more experience to upgrade your ship or buy new ships, and that alone has been enough of a hook for 20 hours of gameplay, but there isn't any personality to the captains or crew, and no overall story to keep me emotionally invested. Still worth a buy at this price point, but I'd love to see a sequel that is fleshed out with a storyline, day/night cycle, stormy weather, crew boarding, and dialogue.

reviewText: Windward proves that the most important aspect of a game is gameplay. The visuals are decent, the soundtrack is nice, but the most important thing is that the game is just pure fun, Its one of those games you can just pick up and play, and not have to constantly look stuff up online or watch tutorials. Its an easy game to just pick up and conquer the high seas alone or with a friend, but with surprising depth in the later game.\n\nI've have yet to encounter any bugs or glitches, even graphical ones. A very solid game.

reviewText: This game does get a little repetitive; for one, the quests are all very similar, and at least for me, the rewards were definitely not worth having to sail from one end of the map to the other, and then sometimes back again (the reward compensation for such a quest is lackluster).\n\nDespite those cons, there is a charm to this game - I've always loved pirate themed games (from sid meier's pirates to AC: Black Flag to even puzzle pirates).  Maneuvering a frigate/sloop/etc is a relatively unique mechanic, and the barrel of fire and poisonous gas plus defensive towers add to the fun.  The combat eventually grows a tad stale, but I'd still say this game is worth it.

reviewText:
If you are like me, you played Sid Meier's Pirates for hours on end. I got this game with high expectations and couldn't help but compare it to SM's Pirates.

Like in SM's Pirates, you start by learning to sail your starting sloop. However, unlike Pirates, this game becomes stricken with monotony very quickly. The quest are incredibly repetitive and lack any kind of meaningful narrative or context. You will find yourself grinding for hours without much reward. The game never develops beyond the first 15 minutes of gameplay.

In addition, there are no interesting conflicts between factions. In fact, you are encouraged not to fight with other factions. Unless you really hate the color blue, you're best off leaving your navy hued neighbors alone.

Pros:
-Fun arcade style combat
-great customization options (from worlds to factions and ships)

Cons:
-repetative
-lacks depth
-lacks interesting context
-lacks any memorable characters, cities, or boats

reviewText:
I sailed the ocean blue.
I acquired all but one of the ships.
I traded cargo between towns.
I killed pirate kings.

It was fun for a while.
The concept, controls, combat, etc. are all pretty decent.
However there is absolutely no storyline, no endgame, and only a very small community.

I wish the developer lots of luck in either upgrading this game so that it has some storyline and sense of purpose or developing another game with these things, but I'm losing interest quickly.

I got it for less than $10 and I don't feel bad for that purchase, but the game could be a lot more.

p.s. Steam makes me say yes or no to recommending this game. I'm going to put yes, but honestly it is a Maybe". It really depends on if you have the money to spare and if you have better games to play at the moment. (And
date: how into pirate ships you are)"

reviewText: This is a wonderful game. A lot of people might consider it too simple, but that's no reason to turn away. Windward is truely a master piece. It's scenery, realistic wind to sail status, and it's music fit perfectly. The music it's self is wonderful, and makes long trips between towns enjoyable and relaxing, while the battle theme keeps to a sea battle pace. All the small jokes inbetween are also great. To top it all off, there is at least one server with 200 players on it regular, fighting on a reaigonal map over territory and plunder. If you're into PvP, try the servers. If you're into quests, perfect. Trading? Sure! And if you just want to ram your boat into the coast line until it sinks...well be my guest! This game is well worth every penny. WE NEED MORE SAILING SHIP GAMES!\n\nMeny people have left. : ( It's still good though, perfect for playing with friends.

reviewText: I bought this because it looks like Sid Meyer's Pirates! but ended up having way more fun with it because of how straightforward it was. Single player drags on a bit at first and it's a pretty nice experience, but heading online to a populated server will yield greater rewards, like faster level gain and better loot. Learn the ins and outs with single player, then once you get it, head online, and join instances. There's an excellent community and the devs are always helpful, in the forums. They also play themselves as I've heard, although I have yet to run into one. The sea battles are a lot of fun, and the trading and questing adds a different flavor to it too, but the meat of the game is online. Windward is wholly enjoyable especially if you like seafaring games. It's pretty much a game made up of the sea battles from Sid Meyer's Pirates! except with added abilities and flair. Don't miss out.

reviewText:
In short: This may not be exactly what you were looking for, but it might just be the best option out there.


The Single Player optionHonestly, this is more of a tutorial than a Single Player campaign.

At the time of this review, only the factions with a player can expand outside of their starting territory. This may change later, but for now it's really just your ship and your faction's AI ships versus Pirates.

A good place to start and learn how to play the game, but a limited experience. It can be great fun sometimes, but experience is limited.

The Co-op optionThis can be a little tricky because it does not use your Steam Friends list or any kind of in-game friends list.

You create a game, just like you would for the Single Player option, and you click the check-box to allow friends" to join. The way they join your game is by specifying the IP address of the host. This may change later.

Unless you want to make a public server
date: this option is great for parents that want to play with their kids
recommended: assuming the kids have their own computer.\n\nThe Online optionOnce you are comfortable with the controls and you know how to play the game
hoursPlayed: this is where you will want to spend most of your time. Here is where you will have the most fun in the game.\n\nFuture patches and updates that change the Single Player option may make that option more attractive
voteText:
but online co-op and PvP is always more exciting.

What you can expect to find online:
Members of different faction
helpfulPercent:
fighting together to beat back a Pirate invasion.
People playing as the Pirates trying to create chaos.
High-level players in low-level areas.
Contested areas where everybody fights for his/her faction.
Epic battles that can last for a very long time.
Faster XP and gold income.
Instances where people from all over the world fights against pirates for loot.

My experience with the gameOn my first day
votesHelpful: I spent seven hours in-game and fell in love with it.\n\nI was hoping to find a game where you can control when your Starboard and/or Port side guns fire and was a bit disappointed to find that they fire automatically. However
votesTotal:
you get used to it and learn to accept it because there is so much more to the game.

I don't use the Single Player any more because the XP and Gold gained from playing on a populated server is great. You can't find decent four-way faction battles anywhere else really.

The game is not perfect. I really wish you could board and capture ships (at least in Single Player)
votesFunny: but it's still a fun experience."

reviewText: Arrrrtastic! You do not have to feed or take care of your crew so its more of an Arcade version of a pirate game, which I prefer for my own style of play. Lots of explosions, the cannons are auto manned so you can focus on special skills. There is loads of room to play as each part of the map leads to another map to play on and you can move back and forth between these map instances. You can get quests from cities or from letters floating around in the ocean. There are map pieces you can get treasure hints from, take landlubbers for a senic tour, bring cargo to build up cities you place, and many more types of quests. Its open world and you can have friends drop in on you to play or you can go onto a server. The game style is mostly about capture the flag: you clear and area around a guard tower, then the city it guards and then plunder the city till it is yours. The game does not require actual numbers of crew so you do not have to spend time gathering and looking for crew which makes this pirate game very action filled on the seas. If you get it on sale you purchased a great deal!! 9/10 (missing a point as it would be nice to control your fleet to follow you)

reviewText: In this game, you start off being able to chose which faction you want to be part of. Each have distinct traits. You then choose map size and difficulty. After that you are thrown into the game. You can trade from town to town, and do quests. As you trade and complete quests, the towns level up, and can provide better items. You get experience so that you may level up, and when you do, get trait points to put into different skills and abilities to use in battle. You fight many pirates, and take over towns to claim the maps as your own.\n\nI personally think this game is really, really fun. It can get repetative, though, because the quests you complete for the towns are pretty much the same. I have yet to get bored because I have been playing the game with my husband each time. I am sure it is probably even more fun the more friends you have - battles can get pretty crazy!

reviewText: One man made this?!?!  Yes he got some help in specific areas, but a single developer coded this game into being from start to finish almost entirely on his own... and it does not suck.  Not at all.  In fact it is pretty damn incredible, especially when you learn the backstory behind it's creation.  On top of that a glance at the forums shows that he is an incredibly responsive developer who engages with the players, built in modding from the get go to allow for community expansion of the game, and is constantly working to tweak and enhance the user experience.  I mean he built a game intended for LAN play that somehow supported 300 simultaneous players in a single game instance running on his home server via cable modem!  That is nutz!  He added server limitation code after that to ensure more managable numbers since this was not intended as an MMO, but it shows the quality of his code work that it worked at all.  How many other 1 person dev teams could put out a game that allows 50 + users enaging in battle simultaneously?  Seriously... Support this game, support this developer, and support others like him who show the dedication to bring great games in to being.  I whole heartedly encourage others to buy this game if it's genere is even remotely interesting to you, it is absolutely well worth it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
BEST PIRATE GAME AT THIS TIME....


A very good game to play.  I have been waiting for a successor to Sid Meier's Pirates!" for a long time now and this is pretty darn good.  It got rid of the sword fighting
recommended: and has no treasure seeking option on land
hoursPlayed:
(this is a pity).

The game play in terms of combat is much better than its predecessor in every way.  It is really good fun in my opinion.  This is one of those games in which I find that after having played for about an hour I find out to my amazement that four or five hours have gone by in a flash!

The graphics are very good.  The game can be readily played without any great learning required.  Customization is well implemented.  Sound is fine.  Very playable.  Easy to use interface.  Instances are a great idea and easily made use of.  You can build new towns as well.

I really enjoy the method of infiltrating and taking over zones one by one and then developing them.  It was a great idea that is implimented in this game.  The abilty to then quickly jump from zone to zone without having to sail there the long and boring way is also a fine idea that works well.  I am playing this game with a lot of enjoyment and belive it to be a well built game.  I rate it 9/10.

My only wish is that there could be a few additional side questing aspects to the game to make it even more captivating.  Perhaps some way of spending part of your loot to create or build things other than for your ship.  Perhaps even a special home base/town that can be lovingly created by the player and added to as time goes by as a personal reward for all of your effort.  Perhaps by treasure questing on land they can find the objects with which to build their monument to themselves. Then having conquered the seas the player can admire and relish owning something customized and created by their own hand as a final personal in game reward.  ( I would really like an excuse to park the ship and go onshore from time to time).

I do hope that with lots of support the developer might add a few more interesting aspects to this already fine game and turn it into a real classic that takes away the mantle from its predecessor.

This game is well worth buying in my view."

reviewText: Realistically, there should be no negative reviews for this game. I would actually just ignore the negative reviews at this point. This game is only $15 and you get so much. It is rare to have a game like this these days. At its core the game is very basic, but there is an art to mastering everything. The developer has given the players unlimited options on how they want to play. You can design the map and specify specifics for each faction. And, if you don't like those, you just start a new map. The other gem here is that you can play single player, p2p, or on servers. Awesome, totally awesome! I mean... argh, I likes the game and the booty!

reviewText: Windward is a bit hard to call.  While it’s fun in its current state, it lacks value.  Certainly not worth 15 bucks.  Very tedious after the first hour.  Perhaps future updates will make it worth the money.  The potential for improvement is what makes it so hard to say no.  As of right now however, the game isn’t quite worth it.  As a fan of the age of sail, and just about every game set in that era, I really hope this game develops quickly and well.
